awd_titl_txt: Elucidating the coevolutionary dynamics in an obligate insect symbiosis
awd_abstract_narration:
Many insects, including pest species that harm crops and transmit disease, depend on symbiotic bacteria for survival. This community of symbiotic bacteria, known as the microbiome, lives inside their host's cells and tissues and is passed directly from mother to offspring. These bacteria often benefit their hosts, for example, by producing required nutrients missing from the diet. But symbionts also can undergo genetic changes detrimental to hosts. This project addresses whether and how detrimental evolution of symbionts affects their host insects. The focus here is on one such group, aphids, which attack most of our agricultural crops and require symbiotic bacteria in order to grow and reproduce. The research will be used as a basis for teaching basic biology and genetics to University of Texas undergraduate students, including participants in a large freshman research program. Also, the results will further understanding of a significant group of agricultural pests, potentially contributing to the development of new methods of crop protection.

The experiments address how genetic variation of pea aphids affects their ability to regulate symbiotic bacteria and how genetic variation of the symbiotic bacteria affects their own multiplication within aphid hosts. The researchers measure how variation in symbiont regulation affects aphid growth and reproduction. Experimental genetic crosses of aphids that vary in levels of symbiotic bacteria will be combined with modern DNA sequencing methods to identify the parts of the aphid genome that affect symbiont numbers. In addition, symbiont strains will be transferred between aphid hosts using microinjection, to determine how different symbiont strains affect hosts.

por.por_cntn:
Endosymbiosis, in which bacteria live within the bodies of host animals, is a widespread phenomenon and plays a major part in determining where and how the hosts can live and reproduce. The endosymbiosis between aphids (sap-feeding insects that include many agricultural pest species) and the bacterium Buchnera is a major model for understanding how endosymbionts affect hosts. This award supported experiments that examined how the symbionts evolve within aphid hosts, how they are transmitted between hosts, how they participate in the metabolism and nutrition of the hosts, and how they determine the range of temperatures tolerated by hosts. One finding is that novel endosymbionts can invade aphid hosts by piggybacking on the Buchnera transmission route from mother to offspring. Another finding is that the temperature tolerance of aphids, which determines where they can live, is dependent on their Buchnera endosymbionts, which themselves are heat-sensitive. Some experiments followed distinct strains of Buchnera within single aphids, using the latest DNA sequencing methods to precisely measure the frequencies of different strains. These experiments found that small genetic changes, due to new mutations, can confer a major advantage that allows the new mutant strain to increase within the aphid lineage, potentially to the disadvantage of the aphid host. Taken together, results from these experiments show that endosymbionts play a central role in determining where and how aphids can live. Similar endosymbiosis occur in a large number of insects, so the results have implications beyond aphids.

As part of this project, complete genome of the pea aphid was determined at the level of whole chromosomes and made available in public databases. The analysis of this genome showed unusual patterns of chromosome evolution that reflect the unusual lifestyle of aphids, which reproduce through parthenogenesis, with females producing genetically identical daughters.

These results have potential as a basis for pest control strategies that target the endosymbionts of pest insects. They also give insight into how endosymbiosis might affect the geographic range of insects as climates and temperatures change. In addition, this project supported extensive hand-on research training for seven undergraduate students, four graduate students, and four postdoctoral researchers at the University of Texas at Austin.
